messages.subject: Tsuba with copper chips in the iron
messages.msgSnippet: Hello to every one, I have a tsuba with tekkotsu in copper, or something like that...., it is a sukashi tsuba with a hawk (I guess) in negative, and a few
messages.messageBody:
Hello to every one, I have a tsuba with "tekkotsu" in copper, or something
like that...., it is a sukashi tsuba with a hawk (I guess) in negative, and
a few stones (guessing too) but it has a few copper chips in the iron,
(looks like koi skin).
I want to know if some one saw this thing on a tsuba before and if is it
traditional?
Thanks for the band width.
Thank you in advance,

http://www.maximom.com.ar/index_archivos/index_archivos/Tsubahawkweb.jpg

Máximo D. Marchionni
www.maximom.com.ar
Maximo@...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba with copper chips in the iron
messages.msgSnippet: I would think the sukashi design represents a sickle (kama), having religious significance as  symbol of Suwa shrine (Suwa myojin), and from a warrior s
messages.messageBody:
I would think the sukashi design represents a sickle (kama), having religious significance as symbol of Suwa shrine (Suwa myojin), and from a warrior's viewpoint used to signify "mowing down the enemy."

The tsuba looks Katchushi to me. I'm afraid I think you are mistaking rust for copper.

David Zincavage
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 27, 2006 1:34 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba with copper chips in the iron


That is a tool or knife I think Maximo, I forget it's name now. The
others circles I think are a variation of Udanuke-ana.

I do not think i would not call that tekkotsu. Are you sure it is copper
?, there is a lot of active rust on that guard.

Rich
